Article Shape-selective synthesis of para-xylene through tandem CO2 hydrogenation and toluene methylation over ZnCeZrO x /MCM-22 catalyst Jie Tuo a Zhenteng Sheng a Xianchen Gong a Qi Yang a Peng Wu a b * Hao Xu a b * a State Key Laboratory of Petroleum Molecular & Process Engineering, Shanghai Key Laboratory of Green Chemistry and Chemical Processes, School of Chemistry and Molecular Engineering, East China Normal University, Shanghai 200062, China State Key Laboratory of Petroleum Molecular & Process Engineering Shanghai Key Laboratory of Green Chemistry and Chemical Processes School of Chemistry and Molecular Engineering East China Normal University Shanghai 200062 China State Key Laboratory of Petroleum Molecular & Process Engineering, Shanghai Key Laboratory of Green Chemistry and Chemical Processes, School of Chemistry and Molecular Engineering, East China Normal University, Shanghai 200062, China b Institute of Eco-Chongming, Shanghai 202162, China Institute of Eco-Chongming Shanghai 202162 China Institute of Eco-Chongming, Shanghai 202162, China * Corresponding author. Selective synthesis of value-added xylenes and para-xylene (PX) by CO2 hydrogenation reduces the dependence on fossil resource and relieves the environment burden derived from the greenhouse gas CO2. Herein, modified MCM-22 zeolite combined with ZnCeZrO x solid solution is reported to catalyze the tandem CO2 hydrogenation and toluene methylation reaction at a relatively low temperature (< 603 K), showing xylene selectivity of 92.4% and PX selectivity of 62% (PX/X, 67%) in total aromatics at a CO2 conversion of 7.7%, toluene conversion of 23.6% and low CO selectivity of 11.6%, as well as giving high STY of xylene (302.0 mg·h–1·gcat –1) and PX (201.6 mg·h–1·gcat –1). The outstanding catalytic performances are closely related to decreased pore sizes and eliminated external surface acid sites in modified MCM-22, which promoted zeolite shape-selectivity and suppressed secondary reactions. Graphical Abstract The modified MCM-22 with decreased pore sizes and eliminated external surface acid sites gives high xylene and PX/X selectivity in tandem CO2 hydrogenation and toluene methylation reaction over ZnCeZrO x /MCM-22 catalyst. Keywords MCM-22 zeolite CO2 hydrogenation Toluene methylation Tandem reaction Para-xylene 1 Introduction para-Xylene (PX), as a value-added chemical feedstock, is in great demand for production of terephthalic acid and high-value polymers such as polyethylene terephthalate [1,2]. The toluene alkylation with methanol (TAM) reaction over ZSM-5 zeolite is one of representative processes for the PX production [3–5]. However, the optimal temperature range (673–773 K) of methanol to hydrocarbon (MTH) as main side-reaction is approximate to that of TAM reaction (693–723 K), thus leading to the generation of gaseous hydrocarbon by-products [5]. Recently, the direct conversion of CO2 to high value-added aromatics not only relieves the excessive emission of CO2 but also offers an alternative non-petroleum route to produce chemicals [6–8]. Two main paths have been reported for the CO2 hydrogenation to aromatics, that is, modified Fischer-Tropsch synthesis (FTS) route over the metal-based catalyst (such as Fe, Co, Ni, and Ru) and methanol route over metal oxide-zeolite bifunctional catalyst [9]. In the modified FTS route, the chain hydrocarbons, produced by reverse water gas shift (RWGS) and subsequent C–C coupling reactions over metal-based catalyst component, further undergo oligomerization, cyclization, and dehydration over the zeolite component (mainly ZSM-5) to produce aromatics in high selectivity [9–11]. Cui et al. [11] achieved excellent performance for CO2 hydrogenation to aromatics over the ZnFeO x -nNa/HZSM-5 composite catalyst, giving total aromatics selectivity of 75.6% with a CO2 conversion of 41.2% at 593 K. The proportion of PX in xylenes reached 75% by selective passivation of the external surface acid sites of HZSM-5. Gao et al. [10] designed the Na-FeMn/HZSM-5@Silicalite-1 catalyst and achieved 81.1% PX selectivity in xylenes for direct conversion of CO2 to aromatics reaction, but the total aromatic selectivity was only ~20%. Although the FTS reaction had been investigated extensively, it remains a great challenge to achieve the commercial application due to low total aromatics selectivity. A bifunctional catalyst of metal oxide and zeolite by the methoxy and/or methanol intermediate route had also been developed to catalyze the CO2 to aromatics reaction [12,13]. Liu et al. [14] firstly reported a composite catalyst of ZnAlO x oxide and H-ZSM-5 zeolite (ZnAlO x &H-ZSM-5), which exhibited aromatics selectivity of 73.9% in CO2 hydrogenation reaction. However, only 20% PX selectivity in xylenes was obtained over this composite catalyst. Tsubaki et al. [15] reported aromatics selectivity of approximately 76% over a bifunctional catalyst composed of Cr2O3 and H-ZSM-5 zeolite (Cr2O3/H-ZSM-5) for the direct conversion of CO2 to aromatics. The PX selectivity reached 25.3% with almost unchanged catalyst activity using a modified bifunctional catalyst Cr2O3/H-ZSM-5@S-1 (silicalite-1) with a core-shell structured H-ZSM-5@S-1 zeolite capsule component. The S-1 shell covered the surface acid sites of H-ZSM-5 core, thus suppressing the undesired side reactions and preventing the isomerization of PX to ortho- or meta-xylene. Subsequently, a series of metal oxides (such as ZnCrO x and ZnZrO x ) combined with ZSM-5 zeolite were developed for direct converting CO2 to aromatics with high selectivity [16,17]. In order to further enhance PX selectivity, ZSM-5 zeolite was modified by selectively eliminating the external acid sites and partial blocking the pore to narrow its openings. However, the product distribution is complex and wide for these bifunctional catalytic systems via the methoxy and/or methanol intermediate route. Among that, the C9 + aromatics always predominate, and xylenes are usually less than 40% due to inevitable excessive alkylation [18,19]. Therefore, it is still a great challenge for highly selective CO2 hydrogenation to xylene and PX due to competitive side reactions. Recently, the toluene alkylation reaction using the CO2/H2 to replace methanol as a methylation reagent, has been proposed over the bifunctional catalysts, where the ZSM-5 zeolite with the MFI topology is responsible for the selective production of PX [20–22]. The in-situ produced methoxy over the metal oxide component can restrain the side reaction of MTH, while the thermodynamic limitation of CO2 hydrogenation can be overcome, due to the rapid consuming of the formed methoxy intermediates on the zeolite component. Yuan et al. [23] reported a bifunctional catalytic system of ZnZrO x and ZSM-5 for the tandem CO2 hydrogenation and toluene methylation reaction, achieving 81.1% of xylene selectivity in total aromatics at a CO2 conversion of ~1%. Meanwhile, the PX proportion in xylenes accounted for 70.8%, significantly higher than that using methanol as methylation reagent (32.7%). They proposed that methylation species formed over metal oxide by CO2 hydrogenation migrated to the ZSM-5 zeolite pore channels to produce xylenes by the toluene alkylation. Shang et al. [24] fabricated ZnZrO x /ZSM-5 catalyst by a simple one-pot sol-gel method to catalyze the CO2 hydrogenation reaction in the presence of toluene, and showed a high xylene selectivity of 86.5% in total aromatics with CO2 conversion of 10.5% and toluene conversion of 24.7%, but the PX selectivity accounted for only 25% in xylenes. This work believed that the high dispersion of metal oxide favors the transfer of intermediate due to the close proximity between metal oxide and acid active sites in zeolite component. These studies provide a promising strategy to synthesize high value-added aromatics from CO2 hydrogenation coupled with toluene alkylation over the highly active composite catalyst, but the xylene selectivity and CO2 conversion are still low. Moreover, these reported catalytic systems required temperatures higher than 633 K for the tandem CO2 hydrogenation and toluene methylation reaction over the ZSM-5 zeolite, which not only led to high energy consumption but also high CO selectivity (> 30%) as well as poor CO2 efficient utilization due to enhanced RWGS side reaction [20]. Therefore, designing a suitable catalytic system that is able to catalyze tandem CO2 hydrogenation and toluene methylation reaction at lower temperatures is desirable. Meanwhile, the low temperature would also help to restrain consecutive methylation and deep hydrogenation reactions of xylenes, leading to high productivity of xylenes and PX. MCM-22 zeolite shows excellent catalytic performance in PX production by the alkylation and disproportionation of toluene reaction benefiting from the shape-selectivity of intralayer 10-ring (R) sinusoidal pore channels and interlayer 10R windows of supercages (Fig. S1) [25–27]. In particular, its interlayer supercages can accommodate readily the bulky bimolecular intermediates involved in aromatic alkylation, which is benefit to lower the reaction temperature in comparison to ZSM-5. Therefore, we reasonably expected that using MCM-22 zeolite to fabricate a bifunctional catalyst for the toluene methylation reaction with CO2/H2 would also bring superior catalytic performance. Herein, a composite catalyst system by combining ZnCeZrO x solid solution with MCM-22 zeolite was constructed to catalyze the tandem CO2 hydrogenation and toluene methylation reaction to produce PX at a relatively low temperature (< 603 K). MCM-22 was further modified via the chemical liquid-phase deposition of silica to promote the catalytic performance, and the relationship between catalytic performance and physiochemical propertied of bifunctional catalyst was also analyzed. In addition, the mechanism of CO2 hydrogenation coupled with toluene methylation reaction for selective synthesis of PX over ZnCeZrO x /MCM-22 catalyst was also studied via the in-situ DRIFTS technique. 2 Experimental 2.1 Chemicals and reagents Sodium aluminate (AR, Shanghai Macklin Biochemical Co., Ltd.), hexamethyleneimine (HMI, Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. >98 wt%), tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS, Aladdin, > 99%), sodium hydroxide (AR, Shanghai Macklin Biochemical Co., Ltd.), colloidal silica (30 wt%, Aladdin), CH2Cl2 (GC, Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd.), HF (40 wt% in water, Shanghai Macklin Biochemical Co., Ltd.), hexachloroethane (AR, Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd.), zinc nitrates (AIP, AR, Aladdin), cerium nitrates (AR, Aladdin), zirconium nitrates (AR, Shanghai Macklin Biochemical Co., Ltd.), and glucose (AR, Shanghai Macklin Biochemical Co., Ltd.) were all used as received without further purification. 2.2 Catalyst preparation MCM-22 zeolite was synthesized following a previously reported procedure [28]. The structure-directing agent of HMI was dissolved in deionized water, then sodium aluminate and sodium hydroxide were added in above solution under stirring for 30 min. Finally, the colloidal silica was dissolved in the above mixture under stirring to form a homogeneous gel, with the molar composition of 1.0SiO2:0.033Al2O3:0.05Na2O: 0.35HMI:20H2O. The gel was crystallized in a Teflon-line autoclave under rotation (100 rpm) at 423 K for 5 d. The solid products were collected by filtration, washing with deionized water, and drying at 373 K for 12 h. The occluded organic species were removed by air calcination at 823 K for 6 h. The solid product was ion-exchanged with 1 mol·L–1 NH4Cl solution at a solid-to-liquid mass ratio of 1:50. This procedure was repeated for three times under stirring at 353 K for 3 h, and then further calcined at 823 K for 6 h to give the proton-type zeolite, denoted as MCM-22. MCM-22 was further modified using TEOS. Typically, a desired amount of TEOS (x wt%/MCM-22) was dissolved in n-hexane (100 mL). Then, 3 g MCM-22 zeolite was added into the mixture and vigorously stirred for 8 h at 343 K. The solid products were collected by filtration and drying at 373 K for 12 h, and further calcined in air at 823 K for 4 h. The above total modification process can be repeated. The modified MCM-22 zeolite was denoted as MSx-y, where x was the weight percentage of TEOS compare to the amount of MCM-22, and y represented the number of repetitions. The reference H-type ZSM-5 zeolite with Si/Al molar ratio of 16 was purchased from Nankai University Catalyst Company. The ZnCeZrO x solid solution was used to couple with MCM-22 zeolite, forming bifunctional catalysts for toluene methylation in the presence of CO2/H2. The ZnCeZrO x catalyst was synthesized by the sol-gel synthesis method following a previously reported literature [29]. Zinc nitrates (Zn(NO3)2·6H2O, 2.95 g), zirconium nitrates (Zr(NO3)4·5H2O, 15.5 g), and cerium nitrates (Ce(NO3)3·6H2O, 1.76 g) were dissolved in deionized water (150 mL) and stirred at room temperature for 2 h. Then, glucose (27.3 g) was slowly added into the above mixture at 353 K and vigorously stirred for 8 h. The obtained colloid was dried at 373 K for 12 h and calcined at 573 and 773 K for 1 and 3 h, respectively. 2.3 Characterization methods A Rigaku Ultima IV X-ray diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5405 Å) was used to collect the powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of the samples in a scanning range of 2θ = 3°–30°. The voltage and current were 35 kV and 25 mA, respectively. The N2 adsorption-desorption was measured on BELSORP-MAX adsorption instruments at 77.15 K to obtain the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface area and pore volume after the samples were activated at 623 K for 4 h in advance. The Si/Al ratios of the samples were determined using inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES) analysis (Agilent 5110). To determine the morphology and crystal sizes, scanning electron micrographs (SEM) were performed on a ZEISS Sigma 300 prime at low landing energy (1 keV, in gentle-beam mode). The element analysis was detected on an Oxford Xplore 30 energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX). High-resolution transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images of as-synthesized MCM-22 zeolites and ZnCeZrO x solid solution were acquired using a JEOL JEM-F200 transmission electron microscope equipped with a 200 kV Schottky field-emission gun operated at room temperature. Raman spectroscopy was used to analyze the ZnCeZrO x solid solution on a Horiba LabRAM HR Evolution. The laser wavelength was 488 nm. X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS) were collected on a Thermo ESCALAB 250XI X-ray photoelectron spectrometer using monochromatic Al Kα radiation. Temperature-programmed reduction of hydrogen (H2-TPR) was conducted on a Micrometrics Auto Chem II Chemisorption Analyzer. 0.1 g sample was loaded into quartz tube and pretreated at 573 K for 1 h in a Ar flow (30 mL·min–1) to remove surface impurities. After cooling down to room temperature, the sample was exposed to a 10% H2/Ar flow (30 mL·min–1) and heated to 1073 K at a rate of 10 K·min–1. The effluent was analyzed by a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). Temperature-programmed desorption of carbon dioxide (CO2-TPD) experiments were performed on a Micrometrics Auto Chem II Chemisorption Analyzer. Typically, 0.1 g sample was pretreated at 823 K for 1 h in flowing He gas, then cooled to room temperature, followed by exposing to 10% CO2/He mixture (30 mL·min–1) for 1 h to be saturated with the CO2. Afterwards, the sample was purged with He flow at 373 K for 30 min to remove physically adsorbed CO2 on zeolite surface and then heated to 773 K at a rate of 5 K·min–1. The desorption curve was recorded with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). Temperature-programmed desorption of ammonia (NH3-TPD) experiments on a Micrometrics Auto Chem II Chemisorption Analyzer was used to determine the zeolite acidity under He flow. Typically, 0.1 g sample was pretreated at 823 K for 1 h in flowing He gas, then cooled to room temperature, followed by exposing to 10% NH3/He mixture (30 mL·min–1) for 1 h to be saturated with NH3. Afterwards, the sample was purged with He flow at 373 K for 30 min to remove physically adsorbed NH3 on zeolite surface and then heated to 773 K at a rate of 5 K·min–1. The desorption curve was recorded with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). The Lewis and Brønsted acid sites were determined using a Nicolet Nexus 670 in situ IR spectrometer after pyridine adsorption (Py-IR). All samples were pressed into self-supported wafers and degassed at 773 K for 1 h. The wafers were exposed to pyridine vapor at ambient temperature for 10 min and then outgassed at 423 K for 30 min. Finally, the IR spectra were recorded after pyridine desorption at 423 K for 30 min. Similarly, the IR spectra were measured using 2,6-ditertbutylpyridine (DTBPy) as probe molecule to characterize the surface acid sites of zeolites. The IR spectra in hydroxyl-stretching region also were collected at 423 K after vacuum at 623 K for 1 h. The xylene-desorption IR spectra were recorded using a Nicolet Nexus 670 with an MCT/A detector and a high-temperature reaction chamber. In a typical run, the catalyst was pressed into a self-supported wafer and localized in the sample cell and pre-treated in pure He at 573 K for 1 h (flow rate, 30 mL·min–1), and then the temperature was decreased to 323 K. After maintaining the He flow for 20 min, the background spectrum was collected. Then, the xylene (PX, MX or OX) was introduced into the sample by He flow (30 mL·min–1) for 0.5 h to ensure the saturated adsorption. Then, the gas flow was switched to pure He with a flow rate of 30 mL·min–1 to start the desorption step. The IR spectra were recorded from 0 to 10 min. The in-situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectra (DRIFTS) were collected on a Nicolet Nexus 670 with a high-temperature reaction chamber to investigate the reaction mechanism. The catalyst (approximately 50 mg) was placed in the in-situ FTIR spectra chamber and pretreated at 673 K for 2 h in H2 flow (30 mL·min–1) and purged with He (30 mL·min–1) for 0.5 h at 603 K. Then, the spectrum of catalyst at the reaction temperature (603 K) was recorded as the background spectrum. Subsequently, CO2/H2 flow (50 mL·min–1) or toluene (5.33 kPa at 303 K) in CO2/H2 flow (50 mL·min–1) was continuously introduced into the chamber. The IR spectra were collected in the range of 4000–600 cm–1 at a resolution of 4 cm–1 at 603 K. The organic hydrocarbons retained in the zeolite channels after the catalytic reaction of syngas conversion were analyzed using gas chromatography-mass spectrometry (GC-MS). The spent catalyst (50 mg) was dissolved in HF solution, and CH2Cl2 was used to extract the organic compounds. Then, CH2Cl2 solution was analyzed using an Agilent 6890 GC system equipped with a HP-5MS column and an Agilent 5977A Network Mass Selective Detector. The hydrocarbon content in the chromatograms was normalized with C2Cl6 as an internal standard for semi-quantitative analysis, and the species were identified by reference to the NIST08 mass spectral library using a literature method [30,31]. 2.4 Catalytic reactions The toluene methylation in the presence of CO2 and H2 was performed in a high-pressure fixed-bed stainless steel reactor with 9 mm inner diameter. For the preparation of the composite catalyst, ZnCeZrO x and zeolite powders were both pressed, crushed, and sieved to granules in the range of 20–40 mesh separately. Then, the granules of the two catalysts were mixed. Typically, 0.25 g composite catalyst (20−40 mesh) with 0.7 g quartz sand was used. After reduced in 30 mL·min–1 H2 flow at 673 K for 2 h, the catalysts were cooled to 603 K, and then CO2/H2 (Vol. ratio, 1/3, 50 mL·min–1) was introduced into the reactor, and then toluene was carried into reaction tube with a constant concentration. The system pressure was adjusted to 3.0 MPa with the flow rate of CO2/H2 at 50 mL·min–1 (volume ratio, 1:3) and the weight hourly space velocity (WHSV) of toluene at 1.2 h–1. Subsequently, the catalyst was heated to desired temperature to start the reaction, and the products were analyzed by an online gas chromatograph equipped with PLOT/Q and FFAP capillary column connected to FID detector and MS-13X column connected to TCD detector. Notably, 4% Ar in CO2/H2 flow was used as an inner standard. The CO2 and toluene conversion, and selectivity of product without CO were calculated. The toluene conversion was calculated according to X toluene = ∑ 6 n C n H m, out - C 7 H 8, out ∑ 6 n C n H m, out × 100 % ( n ≥ 6 ) where C n H m,out are moles of aromatics at outlet. The CO2 conversion (X(CO2) was given by X ( CO 2 ) = ( 1 - A CO 2 out / A Ar out A CO 2 in / A Ar in ) × 100 % where and are the TCD peak area of CO2 and Ar at the outlet,andare the TCD peak area of CO2 and Ar at the inlet. The CO selectivity (S(CO) was given by S ( CO ) = A CO / A Ar out × f CO ( A CO 2 in / A Ar in - A CO 2 out / A Ar out ) × f CO 2 × 100 % where A CO is the TCD peak area of CO at the outlet, fCO2 and fCO are the calibration factor of CO2 and CO. The aromatics product selectivity without CO for toluene methylation was given by S Product, Aro = C n H m, out ∑ 6 n C n H m, out - C 7 H 8,out × 100 % ( n ≥ 6 ) CO2 carbon usages for methylation, C1-C5, CO, and methanol was given by U methy = ∑ 6 n C n H m, out ∑ 6 n C n H m, out + ∑ 1 5 C n H m, out + CO out + Methanol out × 100 % U C1-C5 = ∑ 1 5 C n H m, out ∑ 6 n C n H m, out + ∑ 1 5 C n H m,out + CO out + Methanol out × 100 % U CO = CO out ∑ 6 n C n H m, out + ∑ 1 5 C n H m, out + CO out + Methanol out × 100 % U Methanol = Methanol out ∑ 6 n C n H m, out + ∑ 1 5 C n H m, out + CO out + Methanol out × 100 % The space time yield (STY) of xylene or PX was calculated by STY xylene ( mg ⋅ h - 1 ⋅ g cat - 1 ) = F toluene × X toluene × S xylene × M xylene m cat ( n ≥ 6 ) STY PX ( mg ⋅ h - 1 ⋅ g cat - 1 ) = F toluene × X toluene × S px × M px m cat ( n ≥ 6 ) where F toluene (mg·h–1) is flow rate of toluene at inlet. 3 Result and discussion 3.1 Structure of ZnCeZrOx and MCM-22 The XRD pattern and SEM image (Fig. S2) confirmed that highly crystalline MCM-22 nanosheet zeolite with MWW topology was obtained. The XRD pattern of ZnCeZrO x (Fig. 1(a) shows the characteristic diffraction peaks at 2θ = 30.2°, 35.0°, 50.3°, 60.0°, and 74.3° attributed to the (011), (002), (112), (121), and (022) crystal facets of tetragonally structured cerium zirconium solid solution [29]. As shown in Fig. 1(b), ZnCeZrO x exhibited small nanoparticle aggregates. TEM images illustrated that ZnCeZrO x with a mean size of 5.89 nm had interplanar spacings of 0.297 and 0.260 nm (Figs. 1(c), (d), which is related to the (011) and (002) lattice planes of cerium zirconium solid solution with tetragonally structure, respectively [29]. The EDS elemental mappings of ZnCeZrO x solid solution (Fig. S3) indicated that the Zn, Ce, and Zr elements were all highly dispersed. In the O 1s XPS spectra of as-made ZnCeZrO x and reduced ZnCeZrO x (Fig. S4(a), the lattice oxygen species (Olattice, 529.5 eV), O atom defect sites (Odefect, 530.5 eV), and O atoms in surface hydroxyl groups (–OH, 531.5 eV) were observed [32]. As shown in Table S1, the amount of O defect sites of reduced ZnCeZrO x (28.3%) was higher than that of as-made ZnCeZrO x (26.2%), indicating that the reduction process increased the concentration of surface oxygen vacancies. In the Ce 3d XPS spectra (Fig. S4(b), the u1 (903.2 eV) and ν1 (884.7 eV) signals were related to the Ce3+ species of Ce(3d 94f 2)-O(2p 5), while u0 (900.9 eV), ν0 (882.5 eV), u2 (907.3 eV), ν2 (888.8 eV), u3 (916.6 eV) and ν3 (898.4 eV) signals were attributed to the Ce4+ species [32]. It has been reported that the Ce3+content was related to the oxygen vacancy concentration because the Ce3+ species were coordinated with surface oxygen anions in unsaturated way [29,32]. The intensity of u1 (903.2 eV) and ν1 (884.7 eV) increased over the reduced ZnCeZrO x solid solution, indicating that the formation of surface oxygen vacancies. Therefore, the amount of O defect sites and Ce3+/(Ce3+ + Ce4+) value determined by the XPS spectra of O 1s and Ce 3d (Table S1), as the indicators of the concentration of surface oxygen vacancies, increased over the reduced ZnCeZrO x solid solution. In addition, the H2-TPR curves (Fig. S5) of ZnCeZrO x solid solution showed a strong reduction peak at about 646 K, which is attributed to the reduction of surface Ce species that were unsaturated and coordinated with surface oxygen ions. The Raman spectra of reduced ZnCeZrO x solid solution are shown in Fig. S6. A distinct broad peak at 627 cm–1 was attributed to the surface oxygen vacancies [29]. CO2-TPD (Fig. S7) curves further revealed that the reduced ZnCeZrO x solid solution had surface oxygen vacancies to adsorb CO2. These results indicated that the reduction process could remove surface oxygen atoms thereby leaving oxygen vacancies and coordinatively unsaturated metal sites to promote CO2 activation. 3.2 The catalytic performance of ZnCeZrOx/MCM-22 ZSM-5 zeolite was used as catalyst component in the tandem CO2 hydrogenation and toluene methylation reaction rather than MCM-22 zeolite in previous studies [23,24]. Herein, we firstly studied the difference of catalytic performance over MCM-22 and ZSM-5 under relatively lower temperature (Fig. S8). The toluene and CO2 conversion of MCM-22 is significantly higher than that of ZSM-5 zeolite at 603 K. The composite catalytic system with good activity at lower temperature may be due to unique topology of MCM-22. MCM-22 features an MWW structure composed of three distinct types of pores: sinusoidal 10R channels, straight 10R channels and supercages (12 × 18-R). The supercages in MCM-22 provide open spaces that accommodate bulky substrates [27]. In contrast, ZSM-5 consists of straight and sinusoidal interconnecting 10R channels, which impose steric constraints on bulky molecules. The open reaction spaces provided by MCM-22 could be the reason for the higher activity at lower reaction temperature compared to ZSM-5 [27]. However, the exceptional performance of MCM-22 is enigmatic and warrants further investigation to elucidate the fundamental processes at lower temperature. The effect of reaction temperature on equilibrium conversion of CO2 were considered before using the combined catalyst of ZnCeZrO x and MCM-22 for the tandem CO2 hydrogenation and toluene methylation reaction (Fig. S9(A) [9]. Obviously, low temperatures favor the equilibrium conversion of CO2 in the toluene methylation in the presence of CO2/H2 as well as the CO2 hydrogenation to methanol. Higher CO2 equilibrium conversions are possibly achieved for the CO2 hydrogenation in the presence of toluene compared to the sole CO2 hydrogenation. Furthermore, we calculated Gibbs free energy of tandem reaction and CO2 hydrogenation reaction at the reaction temperature of 603 K, respectively (Fig. S9(b). The Gibbs free energy is 17.944 kcal·mol–1 for the CO2 hydrogenation, but the Gibbs free energy is 7.485 kcal·mol–1 for the tandem reaction to PX. The result indicated that the tandem process can overcome the thermodynamic limitations of CO2 conversion by consuming intermediates of methanol or methoxy species formed during CO2 hydrogenation. The reaction temperature was optimized over ZnCeZrO x /MCM-22 in which MCM-22 had a Si/Al ratio of at 15.4 (Fig. S10 and Table S2). Raising the temperature from 553 to 673 K, the conversion of toluene (from 18.1% to 49.6%) and CO2 (from 2.7% to 15.6%) as well as the CO selectivity (from 8.1% to 29.5%) gradually increased in the tandem CO2 hydrogenation and toluene methylation reaction. Meanwhile, the xylenes selectivity (from 52.6% to 29.5%) and PX selectivity in xylenes (PX/X, from 35.5% to 16.5%) significantly decreased, but the trimethylbenzene selectivity (from 45.1% to 67.4%) was increased with increasing reaction temperature, suggesting that the deep-methylation and isomerization reactions can be suppressed at lower reaction temperatures. The highest space time yields (STY) were achieved for xylene (222.6 mg·h–1·gcat –1) and PX (49.2 mg·h–1·gcat –1) at 603 K. PX is formed over the internal acid sites of zeolite component, which is subsequently alkylated to heavy aromatics or isomerized to other xylene isomers over the external surface acid sites or spontaneously through the thermodynamics effect [5]. The PX selectivity (24.3% at 603 K) in xylenes restricted by thermodynamic equilibrium was unsatisfied over the bifunctional catalyst of ZnCeZrO x /MCM-22. Blocking the active sites on the external surface of zeolite catalysts can suppress deep methylation and secondary isomerization to increase xylene selectivity and PX selectivity [23]. Hence, MCM-22 zeolite was modified with TEOS by the chemical liquid-phase deposition (CLD) method. The extent of modification was controlled by adjusting the TEOS amount in each and repeating CLD process. As shown in Figs. 2(a), (b) and Table S3, the CO2 conversion was nearly unchanged while the CO selectivity was decreased after MCM-22 zeolite component was modified with TEOS. For the four samples of MCM-22, MS4-2, MS8-2 and MS13-2 modified with the different TEOS amounts, the xylenes selectivity and PX/X value significantly increased from 36.0% to 92.4% and 24.3% to 67%, respectively, and the trimethylbenzene selectivity dropped from 59.2% to 7.5% with the increasing amount of TEOS. In addition, for MCM-22, MS4-2, MS4-3 and MS4-4 samples with increased repetition count of CLD process, the xylene selectivity (from 36.0% to 63.1%) and PX/X value (from 24.3% to 59.8%) were also gradually raised. However, MS8-3 with excessive silica modification gave the lower toluene conversion (14.4%) as well as STY of xylenes and PX (186.9 and 120.9 mg·h–1·gcat –1) compared to other samples. The intermediate methanol cannot be fully converted and methanol detected in the products gradually increased (from 0% to 10.2%, Fig. 2(c) with the increase of TEOS amount and the repetition count of silica deposition. Thus, with the CO2 conversion unchanged, the toluene conversion, as well as selectivity of CO and C1–C5 (excluding methanol) decreased, due to the suppressed ability to catalyze the toluene methylene and MTH reaction over modified MCM-22 zeolite with decreased total acid amount [23]. Among all the modified MCM-22 zeolites, MS13-2 showed the best catalytic performance by combining with ZnCeZrO x , exhibiting a high xylenes selectivity of 92.4 % and PX/X value of 67% with a CO2 conversion of 7.7% and a toluene conversion of 23.6% at relatively low temperature of 603 K. The highest STY of xylenes (302.0 mg·h–1·gcat –1) and PX (201.6 mg·h–1·gcat –1) were also achieved over ZnCeZrO x /MS13-2 catalyst, which was beyond reported bifunctional catalytic system for CO2 hydrogenation with toluene feed (Table S4). Moreover, the CO selectivity (11.6%) was much lower compared to previously reported studies (Tables S3 and S4). The RWGS reaction that produces CO is an endothermic reaction [29]. The RWGS reaction was depressed at lower reaction temperature using the composite catalyst of ZnCeZrO x /MS13-2 and thus the CO selectivity was low. Afterwards, MS13-2, as the best zeolite component, was used to combine with ZnCeZrO x for the further investigation of the effect of reduction temperature, proximity between zeolite and ZnCeZrO x , as well as the oxide/zeolite mass ratio on the tandem CO2 hydrogenation and toluene methylation reaction (Figs. S11–S13 and Table S5). As shown in Fig. S11, the low CO2 and toluene conversion were observed at reduction temperature of 573 K due to insufficient surface oxygen vacancies as evidenced by the H2-TPR result (Fig. S5). The CO2 conversion gradually increased, but the PX selectivity slightly decreased with the increasing of reduction temperature. Meanwhile, a volcanic trend was observed for both toluene conversion and STYPX, indicating that the optimal reduction temperature was 673 K. As for the proximity between zeolite and ZnCeZrO x (Fig. S12 and Table S5), upon decreasing the spatial distance between ZnCeZrO x and MS13-2, the xylene selectivity (from 80.5% to 93.6%) and PX/X (from 68.8% to 76.0%) were improved, which was due to enhancement of intermediate transfer from oxide to zeolite. However, for the dual-bed and mortar mode, the toluene conversion was 11.2% and 9.1%, respectively, which was significantly lower than that of granule mode (15.2%). The result indicated that too far spatial distance of two components was unfavorable for the toluene conversion due to the difficulty in transferring intermediate, while the too close spatial distance may cause partial shielding of acid sites in MCM-22 zeolite due to the grinding process (Fig. S14), thus reducing the toluene conversion and increasing the PX selectivity [33,34]. Hence, we chose the granule mixing mode for constructing the ZnCeZrO x and MS13-2 bifunctional catalysts based on the highest STY of xylenes (191.2 mg·h–1·gcat –1) and PX (140.3 mg·h–1·gcat –1). Upon tuning the oxide/zeolite mass ratio, a volcanic trend was observed in the toluene conversion as well as STY of xylenes and PX with the increase of zeolite content in bifunctional catalysts (Fig. S13 and Table S5). The highest toluene conversion of 23.6%, STYxylene of 302.0 mg·h–1·gcat –1 and STYPX of 201.6 mg·h–1·gcat –1 with a CO2 conversion of 7.7% were obtained at the mass ratio of 1:1. Meanwhile, increasing the proportion of ZnCeZrO x solid solution favored the PX/X ratio and CO2 conversion, probably because more methoxy and/or methanol intermediate were generated to promote the methylation reaction over the MCM-22 zeolite. Fig. 2(d) shows the catalytic performance of tandem CO2 hydrogenation and toluene methylation reaction over ZnCeZrO x /MS13-2 with respect to time to stream (TOS). The xylenes and PX selectivity gradually increased with decreasing toluene conversion in the initial stage of 30 h and then kept steady within following 40 h, indicative of good durability of this bifunctional catalyst. 3.3 Structure-performance relationship The MCM-22 zeolite modified with TEOS by the CLD method was characterized via several methods to analyze the relationship between catalytic performance and physiochemical properties of zeolite component. The intensity of reflection peaks in the XRD patterns gradually decreased with the increasing of TEOS amount and the repetition count of silica deposition process due to the deposition of amorphous silica (Table S6, 18.2 wt% for MS13-2 sample) onto MCM-22 crystals (Figs. 3(a) and S15). The SEM, corresponding element mapping and EDX analysis of MCM-22 and MS13-2 zeolite showed the deposition of amorphous silica on the surface of MCM-22 zeolite and increasing of Si element amount over sample MS13-2 (Figs. S16-S17). As shown in the TEM image of MCM-22 and MS13-2 zeolite (Figs. 3(b), (c), the amorphous silica appeared on the crystal surface of MCM-22 zeolite. The N2 sorption isotherms also displayed that the total specific surface area (from 505 to 432 m2·g–1) and the pore volume (from 0.58 to 0.49 cm3·g–1) decreased with increasing TEOS amount and the repetition count of silica deposition process (Fig. S18 and Table S6). To further study the effect of silica deposition on MCM-22 structure and catalytic performance, we chose the representative four sample with increased TEOS amount, that is, MCM-22, MS4-2, MS8-2 and MS13-2. The pore width distribution of MCM-22 zeolite via Ar sorption isotherms (Fig. 4 ) showed that the micropore size was reduced with increasing TEOS amount, and the micropore size followed the order of MCM-22 > MS4-2 > MS8-2 > MS13-2. The variation of shape-selectivity as a result of the change in pore size was confirmed by the desorption behavior xylene isomers over MCM-22 and its modified zeolites using FTIR technique. The p-, m-, and o-xylene desorption FTIR spectra over MS13-2 zeolite are shown in Figs. 5(a), (b) , Fig. S19 and Table S7. PX with the smallest molecular size showed faster desorption than MX and OX, indicating that selective production of PX is possible with the MCM-22 catalyst. Then, we chose MX with larger molecular size as the probe molecule, which have greater diffusion resistance than that of PX and OX molecules, to further analyze the effect of silica deposition on the shape-selectivity of MCM-22 zeolite. As shown in Figs. 5(c) and S20, the bands at 3000–3100 and 2800–3000 cm–1 were attributed to vibration of C–H in aromatics and –CH3, respectively. Introducing He flow to samples, the related signals were significant reduced as a result of MX desorption. The desorption rate, that is the slope of the residual percentage of MX with a function of desorption time, followed the order of MCM-22 > MS4-2 > MS8-2 > MS13-2 (Fig. 5(d) and Table S8). The results indicated that the decreased pore size of MCM-22 zeolite enhanced the diffusion constrains of relative larger molecules with increasing TEOS amount, thus improving its shape-selectivity to the PX product. The catalytic results showed that xylene selectivity of four samples of MCM-22, MS4-2, MS8-2 and MS13-2 were 36.0%, 55.9%, 83.8% and 92.4%, and the corresponding PX/X values were 24.3%, 35.1%, 62.2% and 67%, respectively. Based on the above analysis, we deduced that the CLD of silica enhanced the shape-selectivity of MCM-22 zeolite through decreasing the pore size and thus improved the xylenes and PX selectivity. According to the previous reports, the deposition of silica onto zeolite crystals can not only reduce the zeolite pore size but also eliminate the external acid sites [20,23,24]. Hence, the acidity of zeolites was analyzed by NH3-TPD curves and pyridine-adsorbed IR (Py-IR) spectra (Figs. S21, S22 and Table S9). The total acid amount determined by NH3-TPD gradually reduced from 523 to 437 μmol·g–1 with increasing TEOS amount. The Py-IR spectra illustrated that the contents of BAS and LAS were dramatically reduced from 232 to 120 μmol·g–1 and 153 to 111 μmol·g–1 with increasing TEOS amount, respectively. The external acidity of zeolite was determined by the IR spectra using bulky DTBPy as probe molecule (Fig. 6 ), which is believed not to diffuse into the 10R pores. The characteristic adsorption band was observed at 1616 cm–1 corresponding to the ring vibration mode of DTBPyH+ over MCM-22 zeolite [28]. The band gradually diminished for the modified samples with increasing TEOS amount, indicating that the external acid sites was eliminated by silica coating. The partial elimination of external acidity could suppress the isomerization and deep methylation reactions, favoring the high selectivity of xylenes and PX. The formation of carbon deposition species is closely related to acidity of zeolite [27]. Thus, the hydrocarbons species confined in zeolite channels of spent MCM-22 were further analyzed by GC-MS technique for the toluene methylation with CO2/H2 reaction (Fig. S23). The monocyclic methylbenzenes (MMBs) species, including xylenes, trimethylbenzenes, tetramethylbenzenes, pentamethylbenzenes, and hexamethylbenzenes were detected in the spent catalyst. Meanwhile, the bulky polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs) species, naphthalene and phenanthrenes, that is, the carbon deposition precursors [35,36], were observed over the MCM-22 zeolite without TEOS modification. These PAHs species dramatically reduced over the modified MCM-22 zeolites, indicating that deep methylation reaction was significantly restrained by selective removing the surface acid sites of MCM-22 zeolite via the silica deposition. Based on the above result, the high selectivity and yield of xylenes and PX over the modified MCM-22 zeolites at low temperature (< 603 K) were contributed by two main reasons (Fig. 7(a) , that is, the reduced pore sizes of MCM-22 zeolite resulting in enhanced shape-selectivity of PX, and the reduced amount of external surface acid sites, suppressing the secondary reactions (isomerization and deep methylation) of PX (Fig. 7(b). 3.4 Reaction mechanism The reaction mechanism of toluene methylation in the presence of CO2/H2 was studied. The difference of toluene methylation with CO2/H2 and methanol route was firstly investigated under the same reaction conditions. As shown in Fig. S24, the MS13-2 and ZnCeZrO x /MS13-2 catalysts were used in toluene methylation reactions with methanol and CO2/H2. The toluene conversion, PX selectivity and STYPX were similar for TAM reaction in N2 and H2 flows, but they were remarkably lower than those of toluene methylation with CO2/H2 route. In general, the TAM reaction is favored in the range of 693–723 K [5], thus inferior catalytic performance of methanol route is due to the lower reaction temperature of 603 K in this case. However, for the CO2/H2 route, the methylation step is easier than the methanol route using the formation of active methylation species formed in CO2 hydrogenation step, which can also inhibit deep-methylation and MTH reactions at 603 K [23]. In addition, the XPS spectra of spent ZnCeZrO x solid solution were used to capture the intermediates during the reaction process. The O defect and Ce3+/(Ce3+ + Ce4+) increased over the spent ZnCeZrO x solid solution as evidenced by the XPS spectra of O 1s and Ce 3d (Fig. S4 and Table S1), indicating that concentration of surface oxygen vacancies increased. Moreover, in the O1s XPS spectra of spent ZnCeZrO x solid solution, the signals of O atoms in oxygenate intermediates (H3CO*, 530.8 eV; HCOO* and CO3 2−, 532.6 eV) were observed (Fig. S4(a), which may be the key reaction intermediates in the tandem CO2 hydrogenation and toluene methylation reaction [29]. The formation of surface species on catalyst was also tracked via in-situ DRIFTS technique (Figs. 7(c)–(e)) and S25). The CO2/H2 gas mixture was firstly introduced into ZnCeZrO x solid solution after in-situ reduced at 603 K (Fig. 7(c). The formate (at 2962, 2875, and 2737 cm–1) and methoxy species (at 2923 cm–1) were observed [29], and the peak-intensity of these species gradually increased with prolonging time until a steady state was reached after 30 min, We observed that the intensity of formate species was higher than that of methoxy species, because formate is considered as the key intermediate in CO2 hydrogenation and the further hydrogenation of formate to methoxy is usually the slow step in the whole reaction [24]. Furthermore, when MS13-2 zeolite was mixed with the ZnCeZrO x solid solution, the intensity of bands corresponding to formate and methoxy species generated over the ZnCeZrO x solid solution significantly reduced, indicating that the intermediate may be converted to hydrocarbons over the MS13-2 zeolite (Fig. 7(d). Once toluene was introduced (Fig. 7(e), the formate and methoxy species at 2962, 2875, 2737, 2854 and 2923 cm–1 distinctly disappeared, which should be the result of consuming intermediates by toluene. The result also indicated that toluene methylation with the in-situ formed methoxy and/or methanol intermediate promoted the transformation of formate species. Meanwhile, the new bands at 3073 and 3026 cm–1 attributed to benzene rings and the related bands of –CH3 were observed at the 2978 and 2887 cm–1 [24]. The intensity of these bands gradually increased, and then reached a new steady state after 25 min. Hence, we speculate that these bands are attributed to the aromatics of toluene or xylenes. 4 Conclusions In conclusion, we developed a new composite catalyst system of ZnCeZrO x /MCM-22 that efficiently catalyzes the tandem CO2 hydrogenation and toluene methylation reaction to para-xylene at a relatively low temperature (< 603 K). The MCM-22 zeolite, as a potential methylation catalyst, exhibited a high toluene conversion (40.7%) at low temperature of 603 K, but low xylenes selectivity and PX/X ratio. When the MCM-22 was modified via the chemical liquid-phase deposition of silica, much higher xylenes selectivity of 92.4% and PX/X of 67% with a CO2 conversion of 7.7%, toluene conversion of 23.6% and low CO selectivity of 11.6% were achieved, thus resulting in state-of-the-art STY of xylenes (302.0 mg·h–1·gcat –1) and PX (201.6 mg·h-1·gcat –1). The modification reduced the pore sizes and eliminated surface acid centers, thus promoting the shape-selectivity and suppressing secondary reactions of isomerization and deep methylation. Meanwhile, the in-situ DRIFTS further proved that the in-situ formed methoxy and/or methanol over ZnCeZrO x as alkylation reagents could migrate to MCM-22 zeolite, and further formed xylenes through the toluene methylation process. This work provides a promising strategy and a new bifunctional catalyst system for selective synthesis of PX via the CO2 hydrogenation coupled with toluene methylation. coredata.dc:description: Selective synthesis of value-added xylenes and para-xylene (PX) by CO2 hydrogenation reduces the dependence on fossil resource and relieves the environment burden derived from the greenhouse gas CO2. Herein, modified MCM-22 zeolite combined with ZnCeZrO x solid solution is reported to catalyze the tandem CO2 hydrogenation and toluene methylation reaction at a relatively low temperature (< 603 K), showing xylene selectivity of 92.4% and PX selectivity of 62% (PX/X, 67%) in total aromatics at a CO2 conversion of 7.7%, toluene conversion of 23.6% and low CO selectivity of 11.6%, as well as giving high STY of xylene (302.0 mg·h–1·gcat –1) and PX (201.6 mg·h–1·gcat –1). The outstanding catalytic performances are closely related to decreased pore sizes and eliminated external surface acid sites in modified MCM-22, which promoted zeolite shape-selectivity and suppressed secondary reactions.
